coredata.dc:title: A dielectrically consistent interaction site theory for solvent—electrolyte mixtures
coredata.dc:creator: Perkyns, J.S.
Montgomery Pettitt, B.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A reformulation of reference interaction site model theory is proposed. The approach makes use of the formally correct asymptotic form of the correlations obtained from the one-center angular expansion technique. A modified closure, or equivalently, a modified propagation equation for site—site correlations is shown to incorporate the necessary information to allow dielectric consistency in finite-concentration salt solutions. Examples of the correlations and thermodynamics are given.

Montgomery Pettitt Chemistry Department, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77074-5641, USA Received 28 November 1991 A reformulation of reference interaction site model theory is proposed. The approach makes use of the formally correct asymptotic form of the correlations obtained from the one-center angular expansion technique. A modified closure, or equivalently, a modified propagation equation for site-site correlations is shown to incorporate the necessary information to allow dielectric consistency in finite-concentration salt solutions. Examples of the correlations and thermodynamics are given. 1. Introduction The physical properties of salt solutions at finite concentration have proven challenging for theoretical methods. Formal and practical difficulties are associated with both screening and short-ranged correlations. Neither integral equation theories based on one-center angular expansion methods nor those based on multi-center atomic (site-site) potentials have proven completely satisfactory in dealing with these difficulties using simple closures. In principle both site-site and angular expansion methods can be embedded in exact theory. A wide variety of physical problems could make use of a computationally tractable theory which accurately models the effects of salt in solution. The accurate modelling of biological molecules in realistic aqueous electrolyte solutions is a problem which has recently received much attention but still remains largely unsolved [1,2]. The inherent difficulties imposed by the simulation of electrolyte solutions necessitate enormous computing resources, and even when such are available many thermodynamic quantities are subject to approximations caused by finite sample size, and the slow convergence of fluctuations [ 3-5 ] . Integral equation techniques have proven to be valuable tools in the study of liquids of small molecules and of water-electrolyte solutions, with much more modest computing 626 0009-2614/92/$ 0: requirements [2,6]. However, the practical treatment of polar solute molecules in aqueous electrolytes (three-component mixtures) using integral equations has proven formally difficult. The extension and application of angularly dependent distribution function theories to complicated biological molecular solutes would no longer have the advantage of modest computing requirements. Proper interaction site theories [ 7 ] are not trivial to renormalize. Reference interaction site theories, while still tractable computationally, have inherent problems which manifest themselves in dielectric behavior [8,9], and ion-dependent thermodynamic quantities, which are incorrect, inconsistent or both. The renormalized or extended RISM theory (XRISM) [ 10 ] devised for short-ranged correlations was found to yield a trivial dielectric constant for polar solvents [ 8,9 ]. While this formally incorrect long-ranged behavior only weakly affects the short-ranged molecular correlations of a neat solvent, interionic correlations at infinite dilution would be overestimated without including a correction to give the ions the phenomenological dielectric constant. This arises practically as a simple scaling of the Coulomb interactions in the closure [ 11 ]. Unfortunately, such a scaling is not extendable to finite concentrations of ions. In this case, the dielectric constant derived from the solvent-solvent distribution functions is not corrected by scaling the sol- i.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. Volume 190, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 20 March 1992 vent-solvent interactions; this route to the dielectric constant gives a-1 +3y (y is the usual dipole density [ 8 ] ), whether or not these interactions are scaled. In addition, the dielectric constant predicted by the ionic distributions via the Stillinger-Lovett condition [ 12 ] is also incorrect and furthermore is, in general, inconsistent with the solvent correlation route. This arises from qualitatively incorrect screening and correlations. We present here an interaction site theory which is dielectrically consistent and is based on the judicious choice of a bridge-like function, or equivalently a set of extended site-site correlations based on known asymptotic results. The resulting ion-ion correlations are both dielectrically correct and consistent with the solvent behavior, and this effect arises simply as a coupling to the correlations with solvent molecules, as is the case in real salt solutions; the ionsolvent and ion-ion interaction potentials are not altered a priori. The theory presented is not predictive of the dielectric constant of pure solvent, enabling us to choose the appropriate value for the solvent of interest, but the correct scaling of all correlation functions with mole fraction as salt is added into solution causes a determinate decrement in the resulting predicted constant which is remarkably close to experiment [ 13 ] . In section 2 we outline the key differences between the present theory and the XRISM theory [ 2,14 ] , and in section 3 we present a few key results for a test model. Conclusions are given in section 4. 2. The application of Kirkwood-Buff [ 20 ] (KB) statistical thermodynamics to models of mixtures of ions and interaction-site solvents is a straightforward extension of the work of Kusalik and Patey [ 21 ] . As an example we give the natural logarithm of the mean molar activity coefficients, In (y ), for a range of concentrations, in fig. 2. Unfortunately, solutions to the XRISM/HNC theory were unobtainable below a salt concentration of about 0.5 M making it impossible to calculate ln(y ) using KB theory. (As salt concentration is reduced the Na+Clcontact peak grows enormously and the numerical solution apparently diverges.) Since our molecular solvent theory has a naturally arising dielectric decrement, the continuum model was also solved using the decremented dielectric constant predicted by the molecular theory, so the differences which arise from purely short-ranged molecular effects can be observed. This result, as well as the Debye-Hiickel limiting law (DHLL), are also shown in fig. 2. All results are indistinguishable from the DHLL in the region below a salt concentration of 0.01 M (note the square root units of the horizontal axis) and are 0.0 -0.2 ln(Yt) -0.4 -0.6 -0.8 essentially indistinguishable from each other in the concentration region below 0.25 M. When the concentration of salt becomes higher than this, however, it can be seen that the short-ranged effects of molecular solvent on the activity coefficient are significantly greater than the effect of a saline dielectric decrement. The results from all three theories are qualitatively similar in their upwards concavity to experimental results [ 22 ] , but it should be noted that the exact values for activity coefficients depend significantly on the choice of model [ 18,23,24]. 4. Conclusions A dielectrically consistent site-site interaction integral equation theory makes it possible to calculate qualitatively reasonable site-site distribution functions for electrolytes in molecular solvents. The application of Kirkwood-Buff [20] theory provides a convenient route to calculate mean molar activity coefficients. We have shown the short-range effects due to a molecular solvent are non-trivial for salt concentrations greater than 0.25 M. The current study has made no attempt to adjust any features of the underlying potential surfaces. Due to the extreme sensitivity of thermodynamic properties, such as osmotic pressure and activity coefficients, to small changes in the interionic correlations [ 18,23,24 ] it would be straightforward to re-evaluate various other potential surfaces. The method presented here offers a simple route to calculate the effects of a saline environment on non-trivial solutes. This should be useful for investigation of a variety of problems including salt-induced conformational changes in biopolymers. 0.0 0.5 1.0 1.5 2.0 Acknowledgement Fig. 2.
